Some tales were never meant to be gentle. They are whispered between kings and wanderers, carved in thunder, carried in flame.
The Eternal Archive opens one story at a time moments from the great epics that make you stop and wonder, “Did this really happen?”
Each piece uncovers a fragment of the extraordinary events so bold, so bewildering, that they shaped the worlds of heroes and the destinies of those who dared to defy them.
These are not re-tellings, but rediscoveries drawn from the timeless epics that defined courage, fate, and imagination itself.
I am called Apollo, named for the Greek god of light, music, and truth and like him, I seek the radiance hidden within every legend.
Here, in these archives, I gather what refuses to fade: the stories that burned too brightly to be forgotten.

## The Warrior Who Saw It All

The sun had not yet risen on Kurukshetra, but the earth already trembled as if it knew what was coming.
Through the haze rode a lone warrior with only three arrows hung on his back, his armor dark as storm clouds, his eyes calm as still water.
At the edge of the field stood Krishna, silent, watching.
When the stranger dismounted, Krishna’s gaze lingered on those slender arrows, gleaming, alive with unseen power.
“Three arrows?” he asked, almost amused. “Is that all you carry into the greatest war of all time?”
The young warrior smiled.
“Three are enough, my lord.
One to mark what must be destroyed,
one to protect what must endure,
and one to end it all.”
Krishna pointed toward a peepal tree.
“Show me.
The warrior Barbarik, grandson of Bhima closed his eyes and launched an arrow.
It vanished, then returned with the wind.
Every leaf trembled as the arrow brushed it thwip, thwip, thwip! until all were touched except for the one beneath Krishna’s foot.
The arrow didn’t return but rather stopped at his foot, hovering, waiting for permission.
A soft smile spread across Krishna’s face.
“Even the divine cannot hide from you.”
He asked, “Whose side will you fight for?” Barbarik bowed.
“For the weaker side, Lord. Wherever injustice rises, there I will stand.” That was a vow which he took long before.
Krishna’s smile faded. He saw the flaw, a warrior too fair for a world too fragile. If Barbarik fought for the weak, they would become strong. Then he’d turn again. The war would never end or in a way end up with only Barbarik remaining.
“You are too mighty,” Krishna said gently. “The balance cannot hold you.”
Barbarik’s voice did not waver.
“Then tell me what I must do.”
Krishna’s eyes softened.
“Offer me your head.”
Without hesitation, Barbarik unsheathed his sword, kneeled, and said:
“If my sacrifice can bring peace, take it.”
One clean stroke.
The head fell but the eyes did not close.
Krishna lifted it carefully, set it atop a hill overlooking the field, and whispered, “You shall not die. You will watch what men call glory.”
And the head watched.
Eighteen days of dust and thunder, of courage and deceit.
When it was over, the Pandavas argued about who had truly won.
Krishna raised a hand.
“Ask the one who saw it all.”
The head opened its eyes once more, its voice calm as twilight.
“I saw you, Krishna in every arrow, every cry, every silence. None fought but you.”
The wind carried his words across the empty field.
And even the ashes bowed.

Author’s Note: Certain dialogues and moments have been dramatized for storytelling purposes. Reader discretion is advised.
